Minute Entry for proceedings held before Magistrate Judge Laurel Beeler: Settlement Conference held via Zoom on 7/27/2022. The case settled subject to the contingency of approval of the County, which will take until mid-August. The City of Oakland has secured all necessary approvals. case_data.name: Gaffet v. City of Oakland
case_data.plaintiff_description: All persons who have in the past participated, presently are participating, or may in the future participate in, or be present at, demonstrations and crowd events within the City of Oakland in the exercise of their rights of free speech, assembly, association, petition, and of the press
case_data.summary:
Starting in May 2020, millions of people around the country took the streets in response to the murder of George Floyd by Minneapolis Police Department officers. Thousands did the same in Oakland, California, to condemn the deaths of Black and Brown people by law enforcement.

On April 21, 2020, individuals involved in two of these demonstrations in Oakland in May 2020 and June 2020 filed this putative class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California alleging that the Oakland Police Department (OPD) used blast grenades, teargas, and impact munitions against peaceful protestors. These individuals sought to represent all persons who had in the past participated, presently were participating, or may have in the future participated in, or been present at, demonstrations and crowd events within the city of Oakland in exercise of their rights of free speech, assembly, association, petition, and of the press ("the plaintiffs").

The plaintiffs sued the city of Oakland, the Interim Chief of Police of the OPD, the Deputy Chief of Police of the OPD, Alameda County, and the Sheriff and Coroner of Alameda County ("the defendants") alleging that the defendants violated the plaintiffs' rights under the First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution; California state law; and the Declaratory Judgment Act. Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that the defendants retaliated against the plaintiffs' exercise of their right to peaceably assemble and protest, used excessive force against protestors, wrongfully arrested and imprisoned protestors, targeted people of color who were protesting anti-Black racist police violence, and conspired to violate the plaintiffs' constitutional rights. Additionally, the plaintiffs alleged that the defendants committed assault and battery, failed to intervene, and engaged in negligence.

In their complaint, the plaintiffs asked the court for injunctive, declaratory, and monetary relief. The plaintiffs requested that the court enjoin the defendants from using chemical weapons, explosive grenades, and impact munitions in crowds, and that the court require the defendants to seal and destroy records derived from the arrests of the named plaintiffs. The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on August 24, 2021.

Chief Judge Richard Seeborg granted in part and denied in part the defendants' motion to dismiss on October 1, 2021. Chief Judge Seeborg dismissed only two of the plaintiffs' claims, finding that the plaintiffs failed to plead facts sufficient for their conspiracy claim and for their claim of discrimination under California state law.

In response to Chief Judge Seeborg's order, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on October 22, 2021, alleging facts to support their allegations of conspiracy and discrimination under California state law.

The court ordered the parties to meet for a settlement conference in front of Magistrate Judge Laurel Beeler on March 22, 2022. As of March 14, 2022, this case is ongoing.

The case is ongoing as of March 14, 2022.

1  In this suit, Plaintiffs aver the behavior at the protests at issue violated Oaklandโs own 
2  policies, the federal consent decree entered in Allen, common law duties, statutes, and the state 
3  and federal Constitutions. They seek injunctive relief, in the form of an order prohibiting Oakland

5  arrest records. They also seek declaratory relief and damages. Plaintiffs plan to seek a class action

12  III. LEGAL STANDARDS

uoro 13  Rule 12(b)(6) governs motions to dismiss for failure to state a claim. A complaint must

19  Bus., Inc. v. Symington, 51 F.3d 1480, 1484 (9th Cir. 1995). Thus, dismissal under Rule 12(b)(6)

5  A local government can be held liable if a plaintiff can establish a policy or custom

7  v. Dep't. of Social Services of City of N.Y., 436 U.S. 658, 691โ694 (1978). The Ninth Circuit 
8  recognizes three main theories of Monell liability: (1) an unconstitutional custom or policy behind 
9  the violation; (2) a deliberately indifferent omission, such as a failure to train; and (3) a final 
10  policy-makerโs involvement in, or ratification of, the conduct underlying the violation of rights. 
11  Clouthier v. County of Contra Costa, 591 F.3d 1232, 1249โ1250 (9th Cir. 2010).

8  see these cases are all too common. Dkt. No. 7. In their Complaint, Plaintiffs describe a pattern of 
9  excessive force at protests, andโagain, unfortunatelyโthere is a high chance there will be similar 
10  incidents to protest. It is uncertain whether Plaintiffs will be subject to excessive force again. 
11  Indeed, one can only hope they never even have to attend another protest of police brutality. Still, 
12  the likelihood is high enough that Plaintiffs have standing for an injunction, at least at this early 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  point. Lyons is distinguishable: the chance of one person being put in an illegal chokehold is much 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  lower than the chance of Plaintiffs being subject to excessive force at future demonstrations. 461 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  U.S. at 95. Defendants object that Plaintiffs have not protested again; Plaintiffs note they seek 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  injunctive relief precisely because they do not feel safe protesting again without such relief. 
S d nr
ee 17  Defendants move to dismiss the claim for declaratory relief because it would be 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  superfluous of a grant of damages. They add that the declaration Plaintiffs seek is unclear, but 
19  even if it can be determined, it is unnecessary to clarify any legal issues. For their part, Plaintiffs 
20  note the existence of another adequate remedy does not preclude declaratory judgment. Fed. R. 
21  Civ. P. 57. They also frame the clash here as in part over whether Defendantsโ policies and 
22  practices are lawful. Defendantsโ assertion that no legal issues will require clarification through 
23  declaratory judgment seems correct. That said, for now, there is at least some uncertainty on this 
24  point, so declaratory relief cannot be dismissed at this stage.  
25  D.  Count Six: Conspiracy 
26  Several of Defendantsโ arguments against count six fail, but one succeeds. Count six is 
27  deficient because Plaintiffs have not averred adequate facts from which to infer the requisite 
28  ORDER DENYING IN PART AND GRANTING IN PART MOTION TO DISMISS 
CASE NO.  21-cv-02881-RS 
7 

Case 3:21-cv-02881-RS   Document 40   Filed 10/01/21   Page 8 of 12
 
1  intent. Defendants argue Plaintiffs merely recite the elements of conspiracy without alleging the 
2  unlawful purpose the conspiracy was for, or any specifics of the supposed conspiracy, e.g., the 
3  time or place or persons involved. Twombly, 550 U.S. at 555. It is true, as Plaintiffs note, direct 
4  evidence of conspiracy will rarely be available, even after discovery. Conspiracy is generally a 
5  factual issue best left for the jury if it can be inferred, even if from only circumstantial evidence. 
6  Mendocino Envtl. Ctr., 192 F.3d at 1302.  
7  The issue is Plaintiffs specifically aver only a conspiracy to violate Oakland P.D.โs 
8  policies. As discussed above, they disavow this as the legal basis for their claim. Here, they view 
9  this as evidence that Defendants also had an agreement to violate the Constitution. Even taking 
10  Plaintiffsโ averments as true, that would not be a reasonable inference for a jury to draw. The 
11  Sheriffโs deputies could have ignored Oaklandโs policies and still have followed the law easily. 
12  For example, Oakland requires an Incident Commander to approve the use of chemical agents for 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  crowd control; Sheriffโs deputies could use these agents constitutionally without seeking this 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  approval. It is plausible to infer they were negligent concerning the risk of excessive force; it is 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  implausible to infer they intended to break the law on these threadbare facts. Twombly requires 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  conspiracy allegations to be more specific and more plausible. 550 U.S. at 565, fn. 10. 
S d nr
ee 17  Accordingly, this claim for relief must be dismissed with leave to amend. 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  If the conspiracy claim had enough factual support, Defendantsโ other arguments would 
19  not defeat it. Defendants argue it is deficient because conspiracy itself is not a constitutional tort 
20  under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983. Plaintiffs must show there was an agreement to violate some 
21  constitutional right, and the violation actually occurred. Mendocino Envtl. Ctr. v. Mendocino 
22  Cnty., 192 F.3d 1283, 1301 (9th Cir. 1999). This point is somewhat confusing. Plaintiffs do not 
23  allege conspiracy alone; they aver conspiracy to commit the other torts in their Complaint. 
24  Alameda County also points to caselaw that it takes to mean it cannot possess the required 
25  state of mind for a conspiracy. E.g., Scott v. Township of Bristol, et al., 1990 WL 178556, *6 (E.D. 
26 
27 
28  ORDER DENYING IN PART AND GRANTING IN PART MOTION TO DISMISS 
CASE NO.  21-cv-02881-RS 
8 

Case 3:21-cv-02881-RS   Document 40   Filed 10/01/21   Page 9 of 12
 
1  Pa. Nov. 14, 1990).2 Plaintiffs distinguish the cases Defendants invoke as holding only that 
2  government entities cannot conspire with their own employees. This is known as the 
3  intracorporate conspiracy doctrineโand Plaintiffs rightly note it is unclear whether it even applies 
4  to ยง 1983 cases. Ziglar v. Abbasi, 137 S.Ct. 1843, 1868 (U.S. 2017). Plaintiffs argue a government 
5  entity is a person which can conspire under ยง 1983. Although they point to no direct authority so 
6  holding, a basic principle from Monell is that municipalities are persons for ยง 1983 purposes. 
7  Defendants also object to Plaintiffsโ claim that Sheriff Ahern โand/orโ his agents 
8  communicated to Oakland P.D. that they would not comply with Oaklandโs policies. In their view, 
9  this vague, โshotgunโ pleading makes it impossible for them to respond. The better reading of 
10  โand/orโ is simply that Sheriff Ahern may have communicated to Oakland P.D. through his 
11  agents, and therefore does not create an unmanageable assertion.3  
12  E.  Count 7: Failure to Intervene 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  Law enforcement officers have a duty to intervene, if possible, when other officers violate 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  constitutional rights, as Defendants acknowledge. Cunningham v. Gates, 229 F.3d 1271, 1289 (9th 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Cir. 2000). Defendants argue Plaintiffs have not adequately described the failure to intervene of 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  any Defendants, even the unknown individual officers. They allege Plaintiffs have only recited the 
S d nr
ee 17  elements. Plaintiffs contend they have clearly pled a failure to intervene: they describe the 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  violations happening in plain view of other officers, and note no officer intervened. They argue 
19  this is also proof of the governmentโs failure to train and supervise. Plaintiffs are correct this claim 
20  is adequately pled. Failing to intervene is an omission: only its absence can be shown. How else 
21 
 
22 
2 They also rely on Woodrum v. Woodward Cty., 866 F.2d 1121, 1126 (9th Cir. 1989), which does 
23  not discuss this at all. 
3 Defendants also nitpick various supposed flaws in Plaintiffsโ conspiracy claim, e.g., they allege 
24 
Sheriff Ahern has conspired โfor years,โ but the conspiracy here arises out of protests in 2020. The 
two are logically consistent with an ongoing conspiracy or a series of conspiracies. Defendants 
25 
also argue their purported lies to the media after the protests cannot be evidence of a conspiracy 
beforehand. This seems obviously incorrect. Actions taken after a conspiracy has achieved its 
26 
goals can be evidence of its existence. A coverup is evidence of a crime, albeit weak evidence in 
this case. Anyway, these quibbles are somewhat frivolous, because they concern disputes over 
27 
factual details which would not doom the claim at the pleading stage in any event. 
28  ORDER DENYING IN PART AND GRANTING IN PART MOTION TO DISMISS 
CASE NO.  21-cv-02881-RS 
9 

Case 3:21-cv-02881-RS   Document 40   Filed 10/01/21   Page 10 of 12
 
1  could Plaintiffs plead no officer intervened? While some proof will eventually be required for this 
2  claim, e.g., videos or affidavits, for now this claim survives.  
3  F.  Municipal Liability Claims 
4  Defendants argue counts three, four, and at least one other count should be dismissed 
5  because they were not the โmoving forceโ behind the violations.4 Monell, 436 U.S. at 694. These 
6  counts involve violations of the First Amendment, and excessive force. Plaintiffsโ main theory is a 
7  failure to train and supervise. Defendants insist Plaintiffs fail to allege any specifics. They bolster 
8  their argument by noting a municipalityโs culpability is most tenuous when the claim is for failure 
9  to train. Connick v. Thompson, 563 U.S. 51, 61-62 (2011). Under this theory, Defendants must be 
10  deliberately indifferent to the victimsโ rights. City of Canton v. Harris, 489 U.S. 378, 389 (1989). 
11  Defendants frame this count as elevating Oaklandโs crowd control policy into a constitutional 
12  standard, as discussed above. 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  Plaintiffs argue they have adequately pled all bases of Monell liability, and their complaint 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  makes out a plausible case that Defendants are the moving force behind the constitutional 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  deprivations. Specifically, Sherriff Ahernโs authorization of his deputies to use impact munitions, 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  without sufficient justification, would be enough. Beyond that, the repeated violations by the 
S d nr
ee 17  Sheriffโs Department evidence both a ratification of unconstitutional customs and a failure to train 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  to prevent these customs. In other words, for the second protest in particular, the Alameda 
19  Defendants bear at least some responsibility, not only individual officers. These are adequately 
20  pled to have been the moving force behind the violations.  
21  G. Count Nine: Ralph Act 
22  Count nine claims a violation of the Ralph Act, California Civil Code ยง 51.7.5 The 
23 
 
24 
4 Defendants refer to the third count they discuss in this section as count seven, conspiracy. 
25  Conspiracy is count six, and Plaintiffs discuss count seven, failure to intervene, elsewhere in their 
brief too. Plaintiffs assert Defendants are liable for count eight under respondeat superior, which 
26  Defendants do not mention in their motion or reply. Plaintiffs share some responsibility for the 
confusion, as Plaintiffs mistakenly repeat โCount 11โ to label Count 12 in their complaint. 
27  5 Defendants mistakenly refer to this as count 10 instead of count nine. 
28  ORDER DENYING IN PART AND GRANTING IN PART MOTION TO DISMISS 
CASE NO.  21-cv-02881-RS 
10 

Case 3:21-cv-02881-RS   Document 40   Filed 10/01/21   Page 11 of 12
 
1  elements include that the defendant was motivated by his or her perception of plaintiffโs political 
2  affiliation or protected characteristics. Austin B. v. Escondido Union Sch. Dist., 149 Cal. App. 4th 
3  860, 880โ81 (2007). Plaintiffs contend the officers targeted some in the crowd because of their 
4  race, and some because of their religion; seemingly on the surface inconsistent with officers 
5  targeting them because of their political affiliation or other characteristics. Plaintiffs explain in 
6  response that they were targeted for multiple reasons. There are few facts identified for the 
7  targeting, but the lack of motive for instigating violence makes it a plausible inference, which 
8  must be drawn in favor of Plaintiffs as the non-moving party. On the other hand, Plaintiffs offer no 
9  pleaded facts that any Defendant could have known of any Plaintiffโs national origin or religion. 
10  There are no allegations of visible markers of these characteristics at the protest, or that Plaintiffs 
11  communicated about them to Defendants. Thus, Defendantsโ motion to dismiss is granted as to the 
12  portion of the Ralph Act claim based on religion and national origin, with leave to amend. 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  H. Counts 8 and 10-12: Common Law-Type Claims and Bane Act 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Defendants argue Plaintiffs have not provided a statutory basis for the counts of assault 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  and negligence. Cal. Gov. Code ยง 815; Susman v. City of Los Angeles, 269 Cal. App. 2d 803, 808โ
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  09 (1969). These counts are at root based on common law. Plaintiffs need not, however, cite state 
S d nr
ee 17  law codifying common law torts and outlining defenses. The key issue is whether they have 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  offered enough facts to make out the claim, which they have. Additionally, Plaintiffs note they 
19  cited Cal. Gov. Code ยง 910, when discussing their compliance with the California Tort Claims 
20  Act. 
21  Defendantsโ attack on two additional counts merit no extended discussion here. Defendants 
22  move to dismiss count 11, the false arrest claim, but it is one of the two counts not asserted against 
23  them. (The other is count five, for wrongful arrest.) Also, Plaintiffs assume Defendants challenge 
24  count eight, the Bane Act claim, on the grounds they have not stated the statutory basis for 
25  liability. Yet, it is unclear whether Defendants challenge this claim at all. 
26  V. CONCLUSION 
27  For the reasons set out above, Defendantsโ motion is denied except as to the conspiracy 
28  ORDER DENYING IN PART AND GRANTING IN PART MOTION TO DISMISS 
CASE NO.  21-cv-02881-RS 
11 

Case 3:21-cv-02881-RS   Document 40   Filed 10/01/21   Page 12 of 12
 
1  claim and the part of the Ralph Act claim for discrimination based on national origin and religion; 
2  those parts of the motion are granted. Should Plaintiffs elect to file a further amended complaint 
3  on the claims identified in this order, they must do so within 21 days of this date. 
4   
5  IT IS SO ORDERED.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
26 
27  1.  Police have been targeting, brutalizing, and killing Black people since the inception of 
28  law enforcement in the United States, and Oaklandโs police force has shown a demonstrable 
 
 
No. 3:21-cv-02881-RS Gaffett v. City of Oakland | 2d AMD CMPLT |   1 

Case 3:21-cv-02881-RS   Document 44   Filed 10/22/21   Page 2 of 46
 
1  history of violence against Black people and other people of color in Oakland. This action 
2 
arises out of protests across the nation in response to the May 25, 2020, murder of George 
3 
Floyd by Minneapolis Police Department officers. The events in Minneapolis, soon after the 
4 
deaths of Breonna Taylor and Ahmaud Arbery, brought out millions of people around the 
5 
country to condemn the deaths of Black and Brown people by law enforcement in one of the 
6 
7  largest social justice movements in the United States history.1 
8 
2.  In Oakland, thousands took to the streets on a daily basis starting on May 29, 2020, to 
9 
make their viewpoint known that police brutality and institutionalized racism must end. The 
10 
Oakland Police Department (โOPDโ), and its mutual aid partner Alameda County Sheriff 
11 
Office (โACSOโ), brutally repressed the Oakland demonstrators, targeting protestors with 
12 
13  highly dangerous impact munitions (also known as Specialty Impact Munitions โSIMโ, Kinetic 
14 
Impact Projectiles โKIPโ, or Projectile Impact Weapons โPIWโ), explosive grenades and 
15 
chemical agents, and wrongful arrests.  
16 
3.  This misconduct by OPD and ACSO violated the plaintiffsโ constitutional rights, and 
17 
the CITY OF OAKLAND Police Departmentโs own Crowd Control and Crowd Management 
18 
19  Policy. Said Policy was adopted by the CITY OF OAKLAND and OPD as part of the federal 
20 
court settlement orders in four prior federal lawsuits arising from mass injuries caused by 
21 
OPDโs and assisting agenciesโ (including ACSOโs) constitutional violations, including 
22 
misuse of these weapons and wrongful mass arrests at demonstrations: Coles / Local 10, ILWU 
23 
v. City of Oakland, Nos. C03-2961 TEH, C03-2962 TEH; Spalding, et al. v. City of Oakland, 
24 
25 
 
26 
 
27 
1 Black Lives Matter May Be the Largest Movement in U.S. History, NY Times, 3 Jul. 2020 
28  https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/07/03/us/george-floyd-protests-crowd-size.html, last 
visited Feb. 2021. 
 
 
No. 3:21-cv-02881-RS Gaffett v. City of Oakland | 2d AMD CMPLT |   2 

Case 3:21-cv-02881-RS   Document 44   Filed 10/22/21   Page 3 of 46
 
1  C11-02867 TEH, and Campbell, et al. v. City of Oakland, C11-05498 JST. (See Exhibit A, 
2 
OPD Training Bulletin III-G, which is the Crowd Control and Crowd Management Policy as 
3 
promulgated to the police force.) 
4 
4.  This is a civil rights action for damages, injunctive and declaratory relief arising from 
5 
the unconstitutional OPD and ACSO violence toward demonstrators on May 29 and June 1, 
6 
7  2020. 
8 
II. JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
9 
5.  This action seeks damages and injunctive relief under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983.  This Court has 
10 
jurisdiction over the action under 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 1331 and 1343. It has supplemental jurisdiction 
11 
over the state law claims under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1367.  
12 
13  6.  Venue properly lies within this District under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391(b). The named 
14 
defendants perform their official duties in this District, and the events and omissions giving rise 
15 
to plaintiffsโ claims occurred in this District.  
16 
7.  Plaintiffs JASMINE GAFFETT, KIERRA BROWN and TOSHUA SEARS have filed 
17 
administrative claims with the City of Oakland and with Alameda County, in compliance with 
18 
19  California Government Code ยง 910 et seq. The City of Oakland denied plaintiffsโ claim on 
20 
February 1, 2021. More than 45 days have elapsed since the claim against Alameda County was 
21 
submitted on October 16, 2020; therefore that claim is deemed denied. 
22 
III. INTRADISTRICT ASSIGNMENT 
23 
8.  Pursuant to Local Rule 3-2(e), this action is properly assigned to the Oakland or San 
24 
25  Francisco divisions of this Court. 
26 
IV. PARTIES 
27 
A. PLAINTIFFS 
28 
 
 
No. 3:21-cv-02881-RS Gaffett v. City of Oakland | 2d AMD CMPLT |   3 

Case 3:21-cv-02881-RS   Document 44   Filed 10/22/21   Page 4 of 46
 
1  9.  Plaintiff JASMINE GAFFETT is an adult resident of Alameda County, California. 
2 
10.  Plaintiff KIERRA BROWN is an adult resident of Contra Costa County, California. 
3 
11.  Plaintiff TOSHUA SEARS is an adult resident of Alameda County, California. 
4 
B. DEFENDANTS 
5 
12.  Defendant CITY OF OAKLAND is a municipal corporation, duly organized and 
6 
7  existing under the laws of the State of California.  
8 
13.  Defendant SUSAN MANHEIMER was at all times relevant herein, employed by 
9 
defendant City of Oakland as the Interim Chief of Police, and was acting within the course and 
10 
scope of that employment at all such times. At all material times, defendant MANHEIMER was 
11 
the final policy making official for the Oakland Police Department (OPD), ultimately 
12 
13  responsible for all policies, procedures or omission of procedures, supervision, and training of 
14 
OPD employees and for supervision of assisting agencies brought in as mutual aid to OPD 
15 
during Oakland events.  
16 
14.  Defendant LERONNE ARMSTRONG is employed by defendant City of Oakland as its 
17 
current Chief of Police, and was at all times relevant herein, its Deputy Chief of Police, and was 
18 
19  acting within the course and scope of that employment at all such times. At all material times, 
20 
defendant ARMSTRONG, as the Incident Commander, supervised the response to the June 1, 
21 
2020, demonstration by the CITY OF OAKLAND Police and the assisting agencies brought in 
22 
as mutual aid to OPD.  
23 
15.  Defendant RONALD HOLMGREN is and was at all times relevant herein, employed by 
24 
25  defendant City of Oakland as its Deputy Chief of Police, and was acting within the course and 
26 
scope of that employment at all such times. At all material times, defendant HOLMGREN, as 
27 
28 
 
 
No. 3:21-cv-02881-RS Gaffett v. City of Oakland | 2d AMD CMPLT |   4 

Case 3:21-cv-02881-RS   Document 44   Filed 10/22/21   Page 5 of 46
 
1  the Incident Commander, supervised the response to the May 29, 2020, demonstration by the 
2 
CITY OF OAKLAND Police and the assisting agencies brought in as mutual aid to OPD.  
3 
16.  Defendant RANDELL WINGATE is and was at all times relevant herein, employed by 
4 
defendant City of Oakland as its Captain of Police, and was acting within the course and scope 
5 
of that employment at all such times. At all material times, defendant WINGATE, as the 
6 
7  Operations Chief, supervised the response to the May 29, and June 1, 2020, demonstrations by 
8 
the CITY OF OAKLAND Police and the assisting agencies brought in as mutual aid to OPD. 
9 
17.   Defendant ALAMEDA COUNTY is a political and administrative subdivision of the 
10 
State of California.  
11 
18.  Defendant GREGORY J. AHERN is, and was at all times relevant herein, the elected 
12 
13  Sheriff and Coroner of Alameda County, and the regional commander of mutual aid. Defendant 
14 
AHERN supervises the Alameda County Sheriffโs Office (ACSO) and all its personnel. At all 
15 
material times, defendant AHERN was the final policy making official for the ACSO, 
16 
ultimately responsible for all policies, procedures or omission of procedures, supervision, and 
17 
training of ACSO employees. AHERN is also, and was at all material times, the Law 
18 
19  Enforcement Mutual Aid Coordinator for Region II, which includes Oakland, directing the

response of all regional agencies to requests for mutual aid from the City of Oakland and its 
21 
Police Department. 
22 
19.  The individual defendants are sued in their individual capacities.   
23 
20.  The DOE defendants include other individuals who supervised and/or participated in 
24 
25  the conduct complained of herein. Plaintiffs are informed and believe and therefore allege that 
26 
each of the DOE defendants is legally responsible and liable for the incident, injuries and 
27 
damages hereinafter set forth, and that each of said defendants proximately caused said 
28 
 
 
No. 3:21-cv-02881-RS Gaffett v. City of Oakland | 2d AMD CMPLT |   5 

Case 3:21-cv-02881-RS   Document 44   Filed 10/22/21   Page 6 of 46
 
1  incidents, injuries and damages by reason of their negligence, breach of duty, negligent 
2 
supervision, management or control, violation of constitutional and legal rights, or by reason of 
3 
other personal, vicarious or imputed negligence, fault, or breach of duty, whether severally or 
4 
jointly, or whether based upon agency, employment, or control or upon any other act or 
5 
omission. Plaintiffs will ask leave to amend this complaint to insert further charging allegations 
6 
7  when such facts are ascertained.  
8 
21.  In doing the acts alleged herein, defendants, and each of them, acted within the course 
9 
and scope of their employment.  
10 
22.  In doing the acts and/or omissions alleged herein, defendants, and each of them, acted 
11 
under color of authority and/or under color of law.  
12 
13  23.  In doing the acts and/or omissions alleged herein, defendants, and each of them, acted 
14 
as the agent, servant, employee and/or in concert with each of said other defendants.  
15 
V. FACTS 
16 
24.  On May 25, 2020, Minneapolis police officers killed George Floyd, a 46-year-old 
17 
Black Minneapolis resident. A white police officer knelt on Mr. Floydโs neck for nearly nine 
18 
19  minutes while three other officers observed. Mr. Floyd died calling out for his mother and 
20 
begging for his life as his death was recorded by passersby. The recording was shared on 
21 
multiple media platforms for all the world to witness. 
22 
25.  In the days and weeks following Mr. Floydโs death, people across the country flooded 
23 
into streets demanding an end to police brutality against Black people; protesting the deaths of 
24 
25  Mr. Floyd, Breonna Taylor, Ahmaud Arbery, and countless others at the hands of police, 
26 
through vigils, demonstrations, and public gatherings. 
27 
28 
 
 
No. 3:21-cv-02881-RS Gaffett v. City of Oakland | 2d AMD CMPLT |   6 

Case 3:21-cv-02881-RS   Document 44   Filed 10/22/21   Page 7 of 46
 
1  26.  OPD Command Staff, including defendants MANHEIMER, ARMSTRONG, and 
2 
HOLMGREN, were aware of the potential for large demonstrations to occur in Oakland as the 
3 
weekend drew near, and eventually that a demonstration had been called for that Friday 
4 
evening, May 29. They planned for the May 29 demonstration, including by calling in mutual 
5 
aid through the Regional Mutual Aid Coordinator, defendant AHERN and ACSO. 
6 
7  27.  Also in anticipation of the Oakland protest organized for the evening of May 29, 2020, 
8 
earlier that day, attorneys of record for plaintiffs in the prior crowd control settlements emailed 
9 
defendants MANHEIMER, ARMSTRONG and HOLMGREN, along with Assistant Chief 
10 
Darren Allison, Mayor Libby Schaaf, and City Attorney Barbara Parker to remind them of the 
11 
City of Oaklandโs and the OPDโs legal obligation to comply with the OPD Crowd 
12 
13  Management and Crowd Control Policy in policing anticipated demonstrations (Exhibit B, 
14 
May 29, 2020, Letter).  
15 
28.  Specifically, the May 29, 2020 Letter reminded OPD and CITY OF OAKLAND 
16 
officials that the federal court settlement agreements and orders in Spalding, et al. v. City of 
17 
Oakland, C11-02867, and Campbell, et al. v. City of Oakland, C11-05498, mandate adherence 
18 
19  to the Crowd Control Policy, promulgated as OPD Training Bulletin III-G, in all crowd 
20 
situations, and require OPD and the City to meet and confer with plaintiffs' counsel before 
21 
making any material change to TB III-G and associated training outlines. (Exhibits A and B.) 
22 
29.  The May 29, 2020 Letter specifically mentioned that the Policy prohibits certain 
23 
weapons and types of force in the crowd context and restricts others. Chemical agents and hand 
24 
25  thrown pyrotechnic devices may not be used in crowd events without the approval of the 
26 
Incident Commander, absent exigent circumstances. (Exhibit A, ยถ V.H.4, p. 13, and Exhibit B.) 
27

I.  INTRODUCTION 
26 
1.  Police have been targeting, brutalizing, and killing Black people since the 
27 
inception of law enforcement in the United States, and Oaklandโs police force has 
28 
 
  GAFFETT et al. v. CITY OF OAKLAND | COMPLAINT |  1 

Case 3:21-cv-02881-TSH   Document 1   Filed 04/21/21   Page 2 of 31
 
1  shown a demonstrable history of violence against Black people and other people of 
2  color in Oakland. This action arises out of protests across the nation in response to the 
3  May 25, 2020, murder of George Floyd by Minneapolis Police Department officers. 
4  The events in Minneapolis, soon after the deaths of Breonna Taylor and Ahmaud 
5  Arbery, brought out millions of people around the country to condemn the deaths of 
6  Black and Brown people by law enforcement in one of the largest social justice 
7  movements in the United States history.1 
2.  In Oakland, thousands took to the streets on a daily basis starting on May 29, 
8 
2020, to make their viewpoint known that police brutality and institutionalized racism 
9 
must end. The Oakland Police Department (โOPDโ), and its mutual aid partner 
10 
Alameda County Sheriff Office (โACSOโ), brutally repressed the Oakland 
11 
demonstrators, targeting protestors with highly dangerous impact munitions (also 
12 
known as Specialty Impact Munitions โSIMโ, Kinetic Impact Projectiles โKIPโ, or 
13 
Projectile Impact Weapons โPIWโ), explosive grenades and chemical agents, and 
14 
wrongful arrests.  
15 
3.  This misconduct by OPD and ACSO violated the plaintiffsโ constitutional rights 
16 
and the CITY OF OAKLAND Police Departmentโs own Crowd Control and Crowd 
17 
Management Policy. Said Policy was adopted by the CITY OF OAKLAND and OPD 
18 
as part of the federal court settlement orders in four prior federal lawsuits arising from 
19 
mass injuries caused by OPDโs and assisting agenciesโ (including ACSOโs) misuse of 
20 
these weapons and wrongful mass arrests at demonstrations: Coles / Local 10, ILWU, v. 
21 
City of Oakland, Nos. C03-2961 TEH, C03-2962 TEH; Spalding, et al. v. City of 
22 
Oakland, C11-02867 TEH, and Campbell, et al. v. City of Oakland, C11-05498 JST. 
23 
(See Exhibit A, OPD Training Bulletin III-G, which is the Crowd Control and Crowd 
24 
Management Policy as promulgated to the police force.) 
25 
26 
 
27 
 
28 
1 Black Lives Matter May Be the Largest Movement in U.S. History, NY Times, 3 Jul. 2020 
https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/07/03/us/george-floyd-protests-crowd-size.html, last visited Feb. 2021. 
 
  GAFFETT et al. v. CITY OF OAKLAND | COMPLAINT |  2 

Case 3:21-cv-02881-TSH   Document 1   Filed 04/21/21   Page 3 of 31
 
1  4.  This is a civil rights action for damages, injunctive and declaratory relief arising 
2  from the unconstitutional OPD and ACSO violence toward demonstrators on May 29 
3  and June 1, 2020. 
4  II. JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
5  5.  This action seeks damages and injunctive relief under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983.  This 
6  Court has jurisdiction over the action under 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 1331 and 1343. It has 
7  supplemental jurisdiction over the state law claims under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1367.  
6.  Venue properly lies within this District under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391(b). The named 
8 
defendants perform their official duties in this District, and the events and omissions 
9 
giving rise to plaintiffsโ claims occurred in this District.  
10 
7.  Plaintiffs JASMINE GAFFETT, KIERRA BROWN and TOSHUA SEARS have 
11 
filed administrative claims with the City of Oakland and with Alameda County, in 
12 
compliance with California Government Code ยง 910 et seq. The City of Oakland denied 
13 
plaintiffsโ claim on February 1, 2021. More than 45 days have elapsed since the claim 
14 
against Alameda County was submitted on October 16, 2020; therefore that claim is 
15 
deemed denied. 
16 
III. INTRADISTRICT ASSIGNMENT 
17 
8.  Pursuant to Local Rule 3-2(e), this action is properly assigned to the Oakland or 
18 
San Francisco divisions of this Court. 
19 
IV. PARTIES
